title: Gainesville, Jefferson and Southern Railroad
text:
The Gainesville, Jefferson and Southern Railroad was a <a href="Narrow%20gauge%20railways">narrow gauge</a> railroad in the <a href="United%20States">U.S.</a> state of <a href="Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Georgia</a>.
It was chartered in 1872 and upon completion March 11, 1884, consisted of two lines from <a href="Gainesville%2C%20Georgia">Gainesville</a> to <a href="Jefferson%2C%20Georgia">Jefferson</a> and <a href="Social%20Circle%2C%20Georgia">Social Circle</a>, splitting at <a href="Belmont%2C%20Georgia">Belmont</a>. The portion between <a href="Monroe%2C%20Georgia">Monroe</a> and Social Circle had been acquired and converted that same day from the <a href="broad%20gauge">broad gauge</a> <a href="Great%20Walton%20Railroad">Walton Railroad</a>.
Bankruptcy forced the railroad into receivership in 1897, and in 1904, most of the track was sold at foreclosure to the newly formed <a href="Gainesville%20Midland%20Railway">Gainesville Midland Railway</a>, while the old Walton Railroad became the <a href="Monroe%20Railroad%20%281904%E2%80%931975%29">Monroe Railroad</a>, a subsidiary of the <a href="Georgia%20Railroad">Georgia Railroad</a>. The Gainesville Midland extended the tracks from Jefferson to <a href="Athens%2C%20Georgia">Athens</a>, and was eventually acquired by the <a href="Seaboard%20Air%20Line%20Railroad">Seaboard Air Line Railroad</a> in 1959. <a href="CSX%20Transportation">CSX Transportation</a> now operates the line, though it remains owned by the <a href="Gainesville%20Midland%20Railroad">Gainesville Midland Railroad</a>.
